page.title: 06More Ecology - Butley area
page.content:
There is a famous oysterage situated along the river bank. Mussels can be collected at low-tide. Other paths give views of open farm land when fields are fenced or divided bedges. In many cases shelter belts of trees have been planted to prevent soil erosion and conserve wildlife. There is an large area of coniferous forest commissioned in the late 1920's and also a famous primeval oak wood, called The Thicks, which contains the tallest holly tree in Britain.
Deer, squirrels, rabbits, pheasants and partridges are far more numerous than man in this unspoiled countryside.
